text: This wasn't just some passing interest for Mattis, he pushed hard to get it approved by the Pentagon when he was still a general. So not only did he know a lot about the technology, he knew it wasn't being used when he left the military.

text: I doubt they were "in on it" and they probably didn't know that Holmes was hawking this lie, but....it's weird. George Schultz apparently thought it was being used by the military (that's what he told Tyler when he resigned), so did he and Mattis really never talk about it?
author: AlexParkerDC

text: I get that Henry Kissinger probably knows less than squat about blood-testing science, but you'd figure he'd know enough about how the military works to smell test the claim that still-theoretical tech was being used by troops.

text: The charges against Theranos focus a lot on Holmes' claims that the tech was deployed by the military--a lie she pitched to investors. Prosecution is probably going to raise some weird questions about how her board of gov't luminaries could have missed this.

text: I went to Oberlin, where every woman is supposed to be a patriarchy-dismantling uber-feminist, so imagine my surprise when 10 years later pretty much every one of my female friends changed her name. I think it's mainly to give the kids a break.

text: I tend to think I'm a pretty discerning news consumer with the ability to spot wacky conspiracy theories that dupe others. But if you'd told me about the Felicity Huffman/USC thing last week, I totally would have dismissed it as a nutty conspiracy theory.

text: NGOs like Oxfam feel good about the OECD's min tax proposal. The fact that it's broader than GILTI is a feature, not a bug. The point isn't just to stop profit shifting, but to discourage the "race to the bottom" with rates.
author: AlexParkerDC

text: Wait, are eggs bad again?
author: AlexParkerDC

text: People definitely referred to the excise tax issue this way too. And there are other ways to judge something than whether it's industry-favorable--is it a reasonable extension of the original point of the law? I'm more interested in how it became a symbol.
author: AlexParkerDC

text: But it's not a "tax break for private jets," the way people characterized it at the time. That it went to court indicates that the issue is genuinely tricky, they resolved in a way that's maybe industry-friendly, but that doesn't make it a giveaway.
